title: How to write 10000 words per hour? Is it possible - Quora

response.answer_text: By getting on with it. At my absolute most productive, I could probably do 1,000 words in an hour on my thesis. I’d rather not have to, since it’s quite tiring to do that much thinking as well as typing, but it’s something I could do given the need and the opportunity. Pretty sure I normally end up getting about 750 words in an hour if I’m working hard at it, so the extra 250 shouldn’t be impossible. The trick I’ve used when typing a lot in a short time is to basically shut up and keep typing. I don’t stop to check for references or the exact quotes that I’m after, I just keep going. The result is something like “As Smith has argued, “[INSERT SMITH QUOTE ABOUT ELECTION]” in places, and if I’m desperately unlucky it can sometimes take me 15 minutes or more to find what Smith’s quote actually was (particularly if it turns out it was Jones’ words I wanted, rather than Smith’s at all…), but I push past that and just keep going. Once the timer goes off to signal that I have a break, I stop. Doesn’t matter if I’m in the middle of a sentence or a paragraph (in fact, I’ve read something recently suggesting that it’s better to be in the middle of a sentence, since you can pick up the train of thought more easily when you start again). At a separate time, I then go back over what I’ve written. Odds are that I’ll have repeated myself a bit, left a few sentence fragments lying around, and probably introduced some of my arguments in a less sensible order than I should have done, but that’s what editing is about. The object of the exercise when writing so-many words is first and foremost to write them. Making them the best possible words is the next step.

Dictate it. I taught this trick to some content writers who worked for me and some of them really took off with it. You make yourself a list of bullet points on a scrap of paper. This serves as your outline. Spend another 1–2 minutes prepping in your head and then start speaking. Dragon is good software but you can also use Otter Voice Meeting Notes or Google docs just as easily. Speak clearly and don't get mentally tangled if you mess up. Once you're finished with that section do a quick read through and correct any errors. Having grammarly or pro writing aid helps pick up context errors but good old human eyeballs work best. One of my guys clocked close to 2000 words per hour once he practiced enough. 1800 maybe? That's a lot of words in an hour.
